Views, PREvIEwS
AND REVIEWS


Edward Banks

reached a low level and yet he
claimed to be funny.


The writings of Mark Twain
and James Thurber prove that
comical material can be found
in many subjects. l enjov also
Ogden Nash's and Richard Ar
mour's funny verses.


In the race to get to the moon
and other far off places, l hope
that we will not lose our sense
Of true funny stories.


No doubt when the first Earth
ling reaches Mars, the Marian
welcoming committee will be
headed by a skilled ma ster of
ceremonies who will have a gag
book which would put Milton Berle
to shame. ~''s ia-

piece of furniture in the homeS--
l can remember the records of
several teams using Yiddish or
Jewish accents.


Today we are in the ear of
the indignation jokes. Purveyors
of this type of humor include
Dick Gregory and 'Nipsy Russell.
They take the Negro topic and
make some caustic jokes which
often stun you.


There is a label of "sick"
put on some comedians. Recently
one comedian of this ilk was
banned from appearing in a for
eign country. His material

In view Of the great response to the public
hearing held Monday night at the city council
chambers, there should be little doubt con-
corning support of the proposed city ordi-
nance banning discrimination in places of
public accommodation.


The appearance Of such large group fav-
oring the measure indicates that local atti-
tudes will accept such a law. There should be
no hesitation now on the part of the city coun-
Gil to enact the measure.


Passage of the anti discrimination meas
ure would be a step in the right direction
which might include similar measures in city
employment practices.


1t is good sign that the people Of Phoenix
areproving that they are willing to cooperate
with the city commission on human relations
to implement ways Of improving race re-
latiOnS in our area.

The cloture vote won in the United States
Senate Wednesday morning. This rule will end
the filibuster techniques SO long used by the
SOlons to circumvent bills.


This marks the greatest hurdle which the
proposed civil rights measure had to face in
it's long route through our governments maze
Of lawmaking.


There should be little to hinder the early
passage of the measure which has won strong
support in Congress. The bill is heralded as
the greatest single measure since the end Of
the Civil War to aid in the enjoyment of full
citizenship rights by all minority groups.


All groups, including civic, fraternal and
church bodies should make concerted effort
to write or telegram the congressman from
their respective areas and instruct them to
support the federal civil rights measure.

Humor Week by proclamation
of the gag writer's, comic book
writer's, cartoOniStS and funny
men all over the country.


1t depends on your view how
funny this week has been or can
be. To make a parody on the
sometimes humorous televisiOn
show THAT Was the Week That
Was. It shows promise of be-
coming either a very good pro-
gram or turning into the worlds
worst television vehicle of the
year.


Familiar phrases such as
Hey, have you heard this One?@
and SPsst. come here let me tell
you a funny story, are mouthed
by young and old from Maine
to Hawaii.


Joke writer's have garnered a
niche in our culture and there
are collections of time worn
fables of Aesop to the latest
edition of the Joe Miller group.


Nothing can ever take the place
of a funny story. There may be
many different types of tranquil
izers placed on the market, but
none can replace the pleasure of
humorous tale or cartoon.


In my early childhood can
recall some Of the funny things
that my Grandfather Harry, bet
ter known as Racker, would tell.
He always had ears for funny
ones and he kept us rolling with
some which he brought home.


When he felt like shocking us
he would say, 4Watch out, this
one is a bit sooty." Racker was
full of stories that he picked
up form the men at the coke
and gas plant and later on the
city street cleaning truck. His
job at the coal yard as night
Waterman provided him with
many sad stories as we'll, during
the depression years.


The greatest clowns seem to
have a bit of pathos in them.
Recall, the wistful appearance Of
Charlie Chaplin, the wry wit of
Joe Penner and the elflike CLEAN
of Ed Wynn.


Emmett Kelly, perhaps, one Of
the greatest modern day circus
clowns, was habitually Oh the
verge of tears.


Even Red Skeletons characters
bring a comic relief when the
situations are not funny.


Jackie GleaSon's Poor Soul
character brings a heart pulling
smile when he becomes involved
in some incidents.


The masks of the theaters
which display tragedy and comedy
are closer related than one
imagines. Some sad events are
really funny, but we have been
trained to see most of the heart
break.


What makes you smile, may
on the other hand, make someone
else weep. There is an old Per-
sian proverb which says if joy
comes in the door, watch out
because sorrow is under the
bed.


AS this week ends, remember
that a bit of humor keeps one
not only happier looking, but it
improves your mind. Once Tread
that it takes more facial muscles
to frOWn than it does to laugh.


Unfortunately today many CO.
medians especially on the night
club circuit feel that humOr must
be off color or really dirty.
sometimes this philosophy
reaches into our radio and tele-

full articles.headline: CLOTURE VOTE WINS
full articles.article:
The cloture vote won in the United States
Senate Wednesday morning. This rule will end
the filibuster techniques SO long used by the
SOlons to circumvent bills.


This marks the greatest hurdle which the
proposed civil rights measure had to face in
it's long route through our governments maze
Of lawmaking.


There should be little to hinder the early
passage of the measure which has won strong
support in Congress. The bill is heralded as
the greatest single measure since the end Of
the Civil War to aid in the enjoyment of full
citizenship rights by all minority groups.


All groups, including civic, fraternal and
church bodies should make concerted effort
to write or telegram the congressman from
their respective areas and instruct them to
support the federal civil rights measure.
